DOC.HEAD: Kohl Ends Visit With Appeal for Aid and Patience
Eds: SUBS grafs 2 `At the;' graf 9 `Kohl, who;' and graf 13 `Bild, a' to restore dropped words. Picks up 14th, `Kohl and '
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany recommended Wednesday that East Germany become stronger economically before considering reunion with its rich and powerful neighbor. At the end of an emotional visit to the East, he also discounted fears of a ``Fourth Reich,'' an increasingly used term that raises the specter of Adolf Hitler. President Francois Mitterrand of France, who arrived in East Berlin for a three-day official visit hours after Kohl returned to the West, cautioned against changing borders in Europe. ``For the whole of Europe, it would not be good _ indeed it would be very dangerous _ to reopen the issue of the existing borders,'' he said. Before returning to Bonn, Kohl said ``the economic potential of the German Democratic Republic must be strengthened'' before reunification became a possibility. He said he expected a treaty expanding relations to be completed before East Germany's first free elections, scheduled for May 6. Mitterrand, in an interview with East German TV before leaving Paris, said relations between the two German states have ``very special characteristics.'' He was the first head of state or government of the three western World War II Allies to visit East Berlin. Aides said his trip should not be viewed as recognition of East Berlin as the East German capital, which the Western Allies reject. The United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain still have authority over Berlin as a result of postwar occupation of Hitler's Third Reich. Kohl, who spent two days in East Germany, said at a final news conference his government would address the concerns of other European countries as the two Germanys move closer together. ``It's the most natural thing that Germans want to live together, but we all know it cannot come immediately,'' he said. East Germany's parliament scheduled a session for Jan. 11-12 to debate a new travel law and legislation to promote joint ventures with Western companies. A draft law providing alternatives to military service for conscientious objectors also will be on the agenda, the official news agency ADN reported. Bild, a West German newspaper, said another passage through the Berlin Wall would be opened Friday at the historic Brandenburg Gate, a symbol of German unity. Kohl and Premier Hans Modrow agreed at their summit Tuesday that East Germany woulds open a pedestrian crossing at the gate before Christmas and would lift travel restrictions for West Germans on Christmas Eve. They also signed several agreements and pledged to negotiate a treaty bringing them closer together, especially by expanding economic links. In a commentary Wednesday, ADN said the summit was a success, but ``anyone who hoped'' Kohl would arrive ``with a sack full of Rhine gold rejoiced too early.'' Kohl told reporters inter-German issues that could be discussed soon included improving traffic connections and solving joint telecommunications and pollution problems. ``We will have to work intensively'' on a common German currency, he said, and acknowledged that as ``one of the most difficult questions.'' Kohl said the aim of a common currency was to allow West Germans to buy goods in East Germany. East Germany restricts such purchases because state subsidies make many goods much cheaper than in West Germany, and shortages are feared. In a sign of the rapidly increasing economic links, East Germany announced Wednesday the first joint venture with a West German firm had been signed. A compact disc manufacturing plant is to be built by the Pilz company, based outside Munich, and the East German state conglomerate Robotron. In Bonn, a working group of both nations on promoting tourism held its first meeting. Kohl said West Germany will support reform in East Germany and ``not only talk, but act.'' He pledged, however, to avoid ``destabilization,'' an apparent reference to the power vacuum created by the collapse of Communist Party control over the past two months. Addressing the concerns of neighboring countries, Kohl said: ``Fears based in the past are understandable, but there is nothing to be feared from the future. It's absurd to talk about a Fourth Reich.''
